comment.author: 13423385@N03
comment._content: Suspect this may be Delagoa Bay, Mozambique.

comment.author: 59352877@N05
comment._content:
The paddle steamer looks like one of our family photo's of the ALC fleet that plied from Chinde on the India Ocean coast, a British Enclave just over the sand bar on the only navigable tributary of the Zambezi River, to the Shire River - later to Chindio they went up to Chindio
Delagoa Bay is down by Muputu so why did they put that place on a card with Zambezi River photo's?  Oh what a puzzle.

comment.author: 59356674@N05
comment._content: Erica, if that was the route taken into Nyasaland (Malawi) by early settlers, missionaries and administrators (although I know some had to walk from the coast, perhaps when the Shire was in flood). Maybe the ship from Europe only disembarked passengers at Maputo on this occasion. It's a pity there isn't a journal.

comment.author: 59419369@N05
comment._content:
I have never heard the word 'Slamer' so wonder if that is correct? I have also never heard of early travellers having to walk due to flooding. The main problem was low river levels which meant the deeper hulled boats were no good and they had to use primitive punt like boats of very low draught to get up the river in the dry season. 

The Society of Malawi has been producing a journal twice a year since 1948 covering such matters. It also has a very fine photographic archive including many photos on this Flickr site.

comment.author: 59356674@N05
comment._content: It looks more like Sh..... to me - Sharmer, perhaps, Mike. Will look at the SM site - thanks.

comment.author: 79159520@N00
comment._content:
I think that he caption should read "Sharrer's steamer on the Zambesi" 
Eugene Sharrer a German business man operated a fleet of steamers on the Zambesi and Shire rivers under the company name of " Sharrer's Zambesi Traffic Company"  which eventually became part of the British Central Africa Company.
The fleet included the CENTIPEDE, POLYPODE and MILLIPEDE built in the 1890s by Forrestt & Co. Ltd  of Wivenhoe UK.
I'd have to check my records but I'm fairly sure that the ex Navy gunboat MOSQUITO also was part of the fleet.

comment.author: 60406173@N04
comment._content: It's clearly "Sharrer's steamer on the Zambezi", and equally clearly Delagoa Bay, site of the Mozambique capital Lourenço Marques, now Maputo.

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content: Absolutely fascinating. Description and location amended. Thank you all very much. Mosquito is pictured at www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/5404262893/ I'm noticing.

comment.author: 79159520@N00
comment._content: Taking a very close look at the picture captioned " Sharrer's steamer on the Zambezi" I note that the flag on the foremast is a dark St. Andrew's cross on a white background. This is  the house flag of the African Lakes Corporation. Sharrer's steamers flew a house flag with a white St Andrews cross on a dark background.
